Award.AwardTitle: EAGER: CISSDA: A Unified Cyberinfrastructure Framework for Scalable Spatiotemporal Data Analytics

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Award.AbstractNarration:
Massive spatiotemporal datasets are often collected using global positioning systems (GPS) and other location-aware devices. Spatiotemporal data mining and analysis have become increasingly important as continued growth in geographic information science and technology enables scientific investigations and decision-making support in a plethora of fields. Big data and extensive computational capabilities are needed to mine and analyze the massive quantities of complex spatiotemporal data collected across multiple scales and used for diverse applications. However, conventional methods and tools for spatiotemporal data mining and analysis are developed primarily using sequential computing, and cannot adequately handle this increasing data intensity, complexity, and diversity of applications. Only by seamlessly harnessing heterogeneous and advanced computing and information infrastructure - cyberinfrastructure - can large and complex spatiotemporal data be efficiently analyzed on a wide scale.

This project creates a unified cyberinfrastructure framework by adapting and integrating heterogeneous modalities of computing and information infrastructure (e.g., cloud, high-performance computing, and high-throughput computing) for scalable spatiotemporal data analytics. The framework encompasses two types of novel and complementary capabilities: 1) a suite of methods and algorithms for scalable spatiotemporal data analytics through synthesis of data mining, information network analysis, and parallel and cloud computing; and 2) a geographic information system (GIS) based on advanced cyberinfrastructure (i.e., cyberGIS) to facilitate the use of the methods and algorithms by a large number of users. These novel capabilities help overcome many current limitations in geographic and social science research involving huge amount of spatiotemporal data, and bring forth useful insights for formulating new policies. The framework is designed to gain new fundamental understanding about individual activity patterns and spaces in the domain of environmental health through scalable analysis of massive space-time trajectory data that depict the movement of individuals over space and time. By the ubiquitous use of spatiotemporal data, the project will lead to both transformative and broad impacts on almost all disciplines that employ geospatial technologies for scientific problem solving and decision-making support.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The central goal of this EAGER award, EAGER: CISSDA: A Unified Cyberinfrastructure Framework for Scalable Spatiotemporal Data Analytics (Award #1354329), was to create CISSDA for capturing the characteristics of spatiotemporal data and operations to guide optimal spatiotemporal data mining and analysis, which enables a large number of users and diverse applications to exploit advanced cyberinfrastructure capabilities in a scalable way. Specific scientific investigations focused on gaining fundamental understanding about individual activity spaces constructed based on analyzing large, complex, and detailed spatiotemporal datasets collected using global positioning systems (GPS) and other location-aware devices (e.g. smart phones).

 

The intellectual merit achievements of the project include: 1) an efficient resource management approach to dynamically allocating heterogeneous cyberinfrastructure resources; 2) a suite of new data-intensive spatiotemporal analytical tools for deriving individual activity patterns and spaces that can be used to answer important scientific questions, with examples in health research; and 3) multiple online applications based on cutting-edge cyberGIS (aka geographic information science and systems based on advanced cyberinfrastructure) capabilities to allow a large number of users to interactively explore patterns of spatiotemporal data. Overall, CISSDA drastically enhances spatiotemporal data analytics through an innovative framework for unifying cyberinfrastructure resources and services to enable large- and multi-scale data-driven knowledge discovery. The project team has published more than 30 peer-reviewed journal and conference papers disseminating the scientific and technological advances. 

 

The work done under this award has made significant broader impacts. The powerful spatiotemporal data analytics resulted from the project has been made available to general public, and a broad range of science and engineering communities while enhancing multiple undergraduate and graduate courses to empower interdisciplinary education. The growing cyberGIS community has leveraged CISSDA to enable scientific advances in domains such as geography and spatial sciences, public health, and urban studies. The project’s PIs have played key leadership roles in establishing an international network for fostering data-intensive geospatial health research collaborations; and trained researchers and students on spatiotemporal data mining and information network analysis methods through tutorials, keynote speeches, and invited talks at conferences, industry research labs, and universities. The project team has fostered collaborations with national research centers and industry research labs (including for example the National Center for Supercomputer Applications, U.S. Army Research Lab, IBM T.J. Watson Research Center, Microsoft Research, Boeing, Google, Paypal, and HP Labs) by collaborations with them on data mining, moving object analysis, and text mining research.
